bibl.title: Letter and notes from Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon to Philip Showalter Hench, October 10, 1940

div1.p: Mrs. Agramonte Rodriguez Leon discusses her father's views on Lazear's and Carroll's actions and roles in the yellow fever experiments, commenting specifically on Hench's notes.

div1.head: Letter and notes from Estela Agramonte Rodriguez Leon to Philip Showalter Hench, October 10, 1940
div1.p:
15 Street No. 311, Vedado,
Havana, Cuba.-
October 10th., 1940 Dr. Philip S. Hench,
102-11i Second Avenue S.W.,
Rochester, Minn.
Dear Dr. Hench:

I have read the carbon copy of your notes sent in August very
carefully and found them deeply interesting. I wish to congratulate
you on your excellent and methodical investigation of the Yellow Fever
Story.

In almost every point I think you have arrived at correct and im-
partial conclusions and you have my permission to quote me or my Father
in any of your statements, with a few corrections.

I hope my present notes to your paragraph 103 will not dissapoint
you. I know, by experience, how easily in research work one falls in love
with one's subject. In remarking upon this part of your notes I am really
trying to be absolutely just to Lazear and at the same time historically
exact. There is no doubt in my mind as to my Father's conviction of La-
zear's self-experiment but, try as I may, I cannot recall his having
ever mentioned that Lazear confessed to having done so. I am sorry if I
gave you that impression during our two hasty interviews on the subject.

I have no objection to having this version of Lazear's sacrifice,
which I believe actually existed, made public, and my Father if he were
living would surely be willing to confirm his belief in same. Never-
theless I cannot truthfully quote Dr. Agramonte as having received Lazear's
confession. Perhaps Kean or Truby, though I doubt that they were ever mor-
on terms of greater intimacy with Lazear than Agramonte, may have some
proof of it.

There is a last scruple in the back of my mind. Have you consulted
Lazear's widow about divulging his secret, and are you sure that your
glorification of her husband will not deprive her of needed financial sup-
port?

If so, I agree with you that the dedication of the Lazear Memorial
would be a most appropiate time to make public the quiet and heroic ges-
ture of the man and the scientist. Greater even, to my way of thinking because
he carried his secret of it to a better world, and did not offer himself
to applause or praise. He was an extraordinary personality, and my Father
always admired him for his charmingly distinguished manners and high moral
and intellectual virtues.

I have also made a minor correction to your paragraph 29. Otherwise
I have simply amplified or tried to check you own notes.

A few questions I am unable to answer yet, and understanding that yo
you are by now urgently pressed for time, I shall not try your patience
any longer by making you wait. I shall tryendeavor to send the rest in the next
few days (specially the copy of Reed's letters about Caroll's and Lazear's
illness).

The beginning of the school term has kept me very busy. I finally
decided to devote the holiday of Batista's “coronation” to the job. I
tried to call Mrs. Philips on the telephone yesterday, but could no get in
touch with her. Therefore, with three holidays in succession, I decided
to give you whatever help I can, for what it may be worth, and without
further delay. Please excuse my English and if you quote me, do not
hesitate to make any grammatical corrections. I am typing this off as
fast as I can in the hope of getting it into the morning airmail.

My husband joins me in sending his best regards. Please remember
me to Mrs. Hench.

Very cordially,
Estela Agramonte Rodríguez León.
(Specific remarks on Dr. Hench's notes: Lazear Memorial)-

Paragraph 13.- Your version is quite correct. You may quote Dr. Agramonte
(The Inside History of a Great Medical Discovery) p. 4-5. I have many let-
ters on this point of my Father to Dr. Peabody of Macmillan Co. Dr. P comple
ted a lecture tour of more than 400 high-schools and colleges and was ins-
trumental in obtaining the U.S. pension for the Yellow Fever Board and
Volunteers. One of the two Senators from Mass. who passed the Bill was a
near relation of his. He also contributed largely to the house, cow, etc
given to Kissinger by popular collection, and was naturally quite enthu-
siastic about Kissinger's version of the affair. My Father was able, later,
to disaprove most of it, (Dean's episode in particular) entirely to Mr. P
satisfaction. I'm afraid Dr. A. was not very kind to K. whom he considered
an impertinent an unruly soldier, and only too willing, in after years, to
pose as a martyr in the hopes of mercenary gain. An interesting episode in
Mr. P campaign was during his delivery of the Story of Yellow Fever at a
high school in California. One of the students present introduced himself
later. He was Lazear's son.

Paragraph 14.- I am convinced that it was an agreement between Lazear and
Agramonte. See p. 20, parag. 3 of the Agramonte paper and also p. 19 parag. 1
There were no orders from Reed, who agreed to the judiciousness of their
decision when he returned in October.,(See same p. 20, line 82) thereby ne-
ver submitting himself to the bite of mosquitoes. Lazear, Caroll and Agra-
monte did so many times before Carolls infection.

I remember hearing my Father's remarks on the conscience-stricken attitude
of Lazear's after C infection. Agramonte had trouble in quieting him. Grad-
ually the possibility that C., who had gone out of Camp several times in
the previous days, might have contracted it elsewhere; and C own conviction
that he had caught it in Las Animas autopsy room, contibuted to his peace
of mind. Nevertheless, Dr. A, knowing how severely Lazear accused himself of C's
infection and how passionately he cherished those “loaded” mosquitoes of
theirs, always believed that Lazear might have fed some weakened and starv-
ing insect on himself. In so doing he would have partly disregarded their
joint resolution not so subject themselves to further experiments on the
eve of their important results. He had made A. also promise solemnly not to
rely any more on his own supposed inmunity - all expect Reed, who was away
most of the time, had repeatedly fed the insects on themselves - since he
had been away from the y.f. zone since early childhood. My father used to
point out also, that at that stage of their work the exact number of days
required for the development of the virus in the body of the mosquito had
not yet been definitely established; that frequently infected mosquitoes
were applied to volunteer subjects time and again on successive days without
producing a case of y.f. It was my Father's personal surmise that Lazear
might have risked feeding one of these, though the idea of mosquito trans-
mission had, after C's illness, taken firm hold of their minds. Possibly,
in so doing, his subconcious desire of atonement, for what he considered his
responsability in Caroll's sacrifice, silenced his honourable intention of
keeping his pledge to Agramonte, further justifying himself perhaps, in his
own doubt as to the virulence of some of his specimen mosquitoes which
apparently failed to porduce a cases of Y.F. His pathetic attempts, in his
lucid moments, to convince C. & A that he had not experimented on himself
was gainsayed by his constant and half delirious repetition of his confidence
in his own inmunity after several unsuccessful inoculations, his belief un-
shaken even, after Caroll's and Dean's recent infection. (see Agramonte p. 22)
He later recalled the bite of the “Las Animas” mosquito and the possibility
of other such instances.

All references to Agramonte paper on these pages are from “The Inside History
of a Great Medical Discovery” of which I gave you a copy.
E. A R.

Agramonte believed firmly that there were no yellow fever mosquitoes
straying around the wards, where the patients were naturally kept under
quarantine isolation. Common mosquitoes, perhaps, but aside apart from
the strictly sanitary condictions (wire, netting, etc) the stegomyai speci-
mens which the Board used on its experiments were carefully bred and guard-
ed in their laboratoryes tubes and bowls. No one was allowed to touch them,
(Remarks to Dr. Hench's paper on Lazear)
-2-
outside the members of the board. My Father was sure that if a few y.f. mos-
quitoes had chosen to appear in the Las Animas or Military Hospital wards
where y.f. patients were interned a disastrous epidemic would have rapidly
spread through the hundreds of non-inmune troops nearby. This, fortunately
did not occur; cases were either brought in form distant local sprouts of
the disease or had been exposed to contagion in less strictly watched parts
of the city or garrisons. As thier work progressed, even greater precau-
tions and rules were observed. Actually Lazear believed that the Las Ani-
mas mosquito bite that he remembered had been given bya a common or culex
type.

It was my Father's opinion that Lazear's natural modesty made him shrink
from posing as a hero in what seemed to him, on his sickbed a rather fool-
hardy and unnecessary action after all, perhaps even unfair to the beloved
wife and children far away.

Perhaps these final remarks, which you may quote in any form you wish,
may clarify the basic moral conviction of Agramonte as to Lazear's uncon-
fessed heroism.

Paragraph 17.- There are two or three personal letters from Reed to Lazear
& Agramonte during Caroll's illness. I haven't the time to look them up
for you now, but I came across them when searching for the pictures. Also
a great many personal and extravagant letters to Carolls, himself, quoted
by him in the Donally and Hemmeter papers, and which my Father believed to
be absolutely apocrifous. Really, (I remember reading them a long time ago,)
the style and general tone of the correspondence is very different from
other letters of Reed, the originals of which I have. Also, I believe, a
long cable-letter after Lazear's illness had been notified him, rather
official in tone this last.

Paragraph 19.- Reed arrived a few days after Lazear's death Sept 25. He
returned to the U.S. two weeks later (see Agramonte p. 21, paragraphs 1 & 4)
He read the Board's Preliminary Note on Oct. 24 in Indianapolis, therefore
sailing north before this last date.

Paragraph 21.- Father's notes have the date of Reed's return in November.
Not available today. I will try to send it within a few days.

Paragraph 29.- Dr. Agramonte was not in on the Guiteras experiments at Las
Animas in Aug. 1901. Neither was Caroll supposed to have anything to do
with them. At the start the Cuban doctors were provided with the techni-
cal findings of the Army Board by my Father, but not satisfied with the
irregular way in which the work was being carried on (poor judgment in
selecting volunteers, careless manipulation, etc.) he reported to Wood
and was ordered not to keep out of it. When Caroll arrived my Father
did not know of his participation in the experiments till some time later.
Agramonte never believed that C had secret personal instructions from Reed
to do so, but rather that he thought this might be a chance to “get ahead”
of the rest of the Board in some important discovery. There was consider-
able ill-feeling between A. and C. when the former found out he was being
disloyal to the Board's initial pledge of doing everything as a unit, not
individually. I have a large correspondence, official and otherwise to
that effect; later the Hemmeter episode proved Dr. A. was right as to C
attitude towards himself. Caroll was and odd and ego-centric sort of chap,
suspicious of everybody and inordinately ambitious.

Note: the above is cofidential, of course,. Please do not include my
Father in the Guiteras experiments, a responsability he had the foresight
not to share.

Paragraph 32.- New soldiers quarters were built in 1934 or 1935. Officers
homes had been built by Machado in 1927-1929. I obtained the promise of
Mr. Tomás Roig, our best botanist, to visit the supposed site of Camp Lazear
for examination of the flamboyant tree. He is to give me a written report
of age which he believes very easy to estimate. Unfortunately he is away
from Havana at present, but will return shortly after the change of gov-
ernment (today oct. 10th). I will keep this in mind and report to you soon.
(Remarks to Dr. Hench's paper on Lazear)

Paragraph 50.- Yours Your appreciation of facts is absolutely correct. I am
willing to support your statements at any time. It is perhaps the most un-
biased opinion that has come to my notice on this matter.

Paragraph 52.- The National Hospital of the Cuban Army was named after Agra
monte by Army Resolution of .......... That I know of, it has never been
officially dedicated. I have not been there but I believe Dr. Ramos would
have notified me if any monument had been erected.

Paragraph 94.- Dr. Recio was a good friend of my Father's and I have no
reason to doubt his word but, has he any written statement of Agramonte
in recognition of the tree or the “false” site of Camp Lazear? My Father
was very exact and precise in his statements. It seems odd that I have
found no copy of so memorable a picture among his papers. Amateur phpto
graphy was one of his pet hobbies, we owned and he drove himself, two cars
at the time (1920's). Wouldn't his keen sense of investigation have taken him
immediately and easily to the appointed site to get some pictures of his
own in corroboration of Recio's discovery? More so, seeing thatif “The tree was the
only thing recognizable” in R's picture.
Paragraph 102.- See my notes to paragraph 14.

Paragraph 103.- I cannot vouch for the first part of this paragraph.
Lazear, that I know of, never told Agramonte about having deliberately feeding
an infected mosquito on himself after their agreement. It was my Father's con
viction that he had done so/. I have tried to give as accurate an account
as I can of my Father's opinion on the matter in my notes to paragraph 14.
It is my opinion that you can build up a very beautiful picture of his mental
conflict and possible inoculation. I can not find any record in my Father's
papers that he actually confessed to having subjected himself to infection.
If he had really infected himself he rather sheepishly tried to explain it
away when stricken with y.f. A further search in Agramonte's papers may per
haps bring to light the above, but I doubt it. You are very welcome to go
over them at any future time, and I hope you will have the opportunity to
do so. I am sorry, but I cannot historically accept the first 10 lines
of paragraph 103. (carbon copy of notes sent to me)

Paragraph 104.- I do not remember quoting that Lazear fell ill 8 days af-
ter any set date of inoculation. I do no know enough about the medical
picture of y.f. to mention technical data You may have misunderstood my
statement that, in trying to acquit himself of blame in Caroll's inocula-
tion, he told my Father he had often allowed himself to be bitten by those
same mosquitoes on the days prior to C's experiment. I can even imagine
him having fed caroll's own mosquito, not acquiringcontracting the disease then be-
cause the bug was not sufficiently “ripe” at the time.

Paragraph 105.- I am sending you my Father's longhand notes on his speech
at the Gorgas and Kean banquet. You have my permission to have a photostatic
copy made; perhaps, by passing india-ink over the pencil writing, it will
become legible in print.

I do not quite see your angle of what you term the Agramonte “hint”.
He may have referred to a voluntary inoculation (his own personal convic-
tion) but then again he may also simply refer to one of Lazear's many bites
immediately before their pledge or mututal agreement. Also possibly in-
cluding a “dig” to Caroll's accidentala and not experimental inoculation
, seeingin view of the fact that they all, and C especially, did not fully believe in the
virulence of those mosquitoes.

You may of course quote Dr. AGramonte, but whatever conclusions you
arrive at about the matter, please give them as your own.

Dr. AGramonte's ashes are buried in Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn my Moth
ers family plot (her maiden name was Pierra) He was cremated in New York.
A small headstone marks the place, I have never been in condition to afford
bringing himhis remains down near here where I should like to have them
(Remarks to Dr. Hench's paper on Lazear)

2-I believe many of my Father's papers to be in the “Louisiana State Medical
Centre, Agramonte Memorial Library, to which we donated his large medical
library with many valuable autographs of scientific interest. I am afraid
some private correspondence was mistakenly removed with the books, as quite
a few personal things have been traced there in later years, by my Mother
and myself. Sometime I hope to visit the place which, I have been told, is
really beautiful. The only monument I know erected to his memory and that
of the Board with the exception of a small tablets to Lazear in the Columbia
Alumni Hall of Fame, to whichwhere they intended to add one to Agramonte. By
the way, Agramonte was largely responsible for this small memorial to Lazear;
around this subject he published several articles, a few letters and a short
address on his life and works. (x)

3-Since you mention the Agramonte article in Scientific Monthly, Dec 1915.
you are acquainted with the small pen and ink drawings or plans made by
him of Camp Lazear buildings. I have copies of same, his handwriting is cl
clearly discernible on the reprints in the article.

4-I am enclsing a little picture I found interesting. Is it the same site
of Las Animas or Military Hospital where the other picture of Lazear, Caroll
and Agramonte was taken? Can you possibly identify it by your later inspec-
tions of old photographs in Washington? Caroll may be the man with my Father
though not in uniform; possibly during his second visit in Havana. Could it
be Dr. Rojas and this one of the two buildings on Camp Lazear? it seems too
open a house for the mosquito experiments, and is undoubtedly madapparently built of brick
and cement. Please return, as it is my only copy of same.

(x) Also a small exhibit, dedicated to the Board in the Natural
History Museum of N. Y.
